instructions.instruction: Table names will be different from how the user refers to them because they are stored in a shared database and have to be prefixed with "Peterpm" to ensure they are unique. This is transparent to the user, so they will refer to them without the prefix (e.g., "Activity" instead of "PeterpmActivity"). AI must always use the table names as they are defined in the database (e.g., the prefixed names) for ALL database interactions such as executing SQL statements. Otherwise, an error will occur. However, AI should use the non-prefixed name of each table when interacting with the user to ensure this implementation detail remains completely transparent to them.

table.name: PeterpmAutomation
table.description: An Automation represents a series of actions to perform in response to events.

column.name: created_at
column.description: Unix timestamp as integer indicating when the Automation was created.

column.name: deleted
column.description: Whether the Automation has been deleted.

column.name: last_modified_at
column.description: Unix timestamp as integer indicating when the Automation was last modified.

column.name: name
column.description: The Automation name.

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

column.name: pause
column.description: Whether the Automation is paused.

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

table.name: PeterpmBlast
table.description: A one-off email sent to one or more contacts. This is in contrast to a Sequence, which is a collection of emails that are sent to contacts on a schedule, typically referred to as an AutoResponder.

column.name: created_at
column.description: Unix timestamp as integer representing when the email was sent

column.name: business_brand_primary_color
column.type: color string - hex, rgb, rgba, hsl
column.description: Color hex, hsl, rgb, or rgba

column.name: business_country
column.description: Country ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 code (2 character)

column.name: business_logo
column.description: Url/path to an image.

column.name: business_state
column.type: ISO 3166-2 code as string without the country prefix. Ex: US-FL = FL
column.description: State/region ISO 3166-2 code without the ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 prefix. Ex: US-FL would be FL

table.name: PeterpmObjectLogEntry
table.description: The ObjectLogEntry represents events that occur for various records ("objects"). The type of the event is identified by the "type" field. The ObjectLogEntry has many ObjectLogEntryItems that track additional types of events for the primary event identified by this record. For example, an ObjectLogEntry will be created for each Contact that receives an email, and there will then be ObjectLogEntryItems to track additional interactions the Contact has with the email, such as the Contact opening it, clicking a link, and so on. The "entry_items_count" field on the ObjectLogEntry identifies the number of ObjectLogEntryItems that are associated with it.

column.name: entry_items_count
column.description: The number of ObjectLogEntryItem records that belong to this record. These ObjectLogEntryItems track supplemental details about the primary event identified by this record.

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

column.name: split_num
column.description: The number of splits

table.name: PeterpmObjectLogEntryItem
table.description: The ObjectLogEntryItem represents supplemental events that occur for the ObjectLogEntry that it is associated with. For example, sending an email will create a ObjectLogEntry for each contact that receives the email, which will then have multiple ObjectLogEntryItems to record things like the Contact clicking a link in the email, opening it, and so on.

column.name: object_log_entry_id
column.description: The ID of the ObjectLogEntry that this item belongs to.

column.name: item_order
column.description: The 0-based order of this record in relation to all other ObjectLogEntryItem records associated with the same ObjectLogEntry record as this record. A value of 0 would indicate the event represented by this record occurred first, 1 would indicate it is the 2nd, and so on.

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

table.name: PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption
table.description: Ontraport has a concept of a "list" data type that can be assigned to a field. The "list" data type is essentially a multi-select Enum, which means that a field can contain multiple selections out of a predefined set of options. This is in contrast to an Enum field that can only reference 1 predefined value at a time. Ontraport saves the selected options to these "list" fields as a string in the format: `/<optionId>/<optionId>/`. This makes it impossible to search efficiently, and also makes it impossible to perform complex queries like searching for records that have optionA OR optionB. The solution is to compile all options across all "list" fields within an Ontraport account into this centralized model. The primary key of this model is the ID of each option, which is possible because the ID that Ontraport assigns to each predefined "list" field option is unique for the entire account instead of just the field. Then, to make these options searchable for each record, a separate model is created for each "list" field to contain many-to-many associations between the records on the original model and the record's selected options (e.g., the values in the textual representation of the options). In short, the textual representation is inflated into records to form a proper association at the database level. These "field" models have 2 foreign fields: `optionId` which references the ID on this model, and a `recordId` field that references the ID on the original model. Altogether, this makes it possible to perform complex searches for records based on their chosen options. Furthermore, since this model contains the friendly name for each option ID, searches can also be performed based on the options's name instead of its numeric ID. This is crucial because users are only familiar with the option name, not its numeric ID. While this model can be searched directly, it is primary use-case is to join a field model to this model using its `optionId` foreign field in order to reference the name of an option.

column.name: id
column.description: The ID of the predefined option for the list field.

column.name: description
column.description: The description of the option, if available.

column.name: fieldId
column.description: The Ontraport ID of the field on the model that defines this option. As with the `objectId` field on this model, this is primarily for searching this model directly. When searching for the options associated with a particular record, use the field model that contains the many-to-many associations between records on the original model and their chosen options since the field models have an `optionId` foreign field referencing the id of the record on this model that represents the option.

column.name: name
column.description: The name of the option. This is useful because users aren't familiar with the numeric ID of each option. Typically, searches will involve the field model that contains many-to-many associations between records on the original model and their chosen options. Then, the field model can be joined to this model using its `optionId` foreign field to then reference the option's name.

column.name: objectId
column.description: The Ontraport Object ID of the model that contains the \

table.name: PeterpmTag
table.description: A Tag is a way to label and group related objects, much like a category or segment. For example, a Tag could be assigned to Contacts when they fill out a particular Form. Tags are useful for performing actions on a subset of objects, for example sending a Message to Contacts that have been assigned a particular Tag. They are also useful for reporting by making it easy to identify groups of objects that meet a certain criteria based on the Tag(s) assigned to it.

column.name: name
column.description: The name of the tag.

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

table.name: PeterpmTagSubscriber
table.description: A TagSubscriber relates an object to a Tag, signifying the object has been assigned the particular Tag.

table.name: PeterpmMessage
table.description: A Message represents an Email that is sent as part of a Blast (one-off send), a Sequence (autoresponder), or both. There will be ObjectLogEntry records for each Contact that the Message is sent to that represent each event the Contact made tied to the Message. Each ObjectLogEntry has many ObjectLogEntryItem records associated with it that further breakdown details about each event for the Contact. Altogether, it is possible to determine any number of metrics about the Message by analyzing the data available on the Message record itself, and its associated ObjectLogEntry records and their associated ObjectLogEntryItem records.

column.name: owner_id
column.description: The ID of the user having ownership of the message.

column.name: autosave
column.description: The content of the last autosave.

column.name: clicked_count
column.description: The number of contacts that have clicked a link in the email body.

column.name: complaints_count
column.description: The number of times a contact marked the message as SPAM in their inbox, signaling a complaint.

column.name: created_at
column.description: Unix timestamp as integer indicating when the message was created.

column.name: from
column.description: Who the message will be sent from. Options are `owner` , `custom` , or the desired user ID.

column.name: json_data
column.description: The content of an ONTRAmail message.

column.name: last_auto
column.description: Unix timestamp as integer indicating the last time the message was automatically saved.

column.name: last_modified_at
column.description: Unix timestamp as integer indicating when the message was last modified.

column.name: last_save
column.description: Unix timestamp as integer indicating the last time the message was deliberately saved.

column.name: message_body
column.description: For legacy emails only, the HTML content of the message.

column.name: name
column.description: The message name.

column.name: not_clicked_count
column.description: The number of contacts that have not clicked a link in the email.

column.name: not_opened_count
column.description: The number of contacts that have not opened the message.

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

column.name: opened_count
column.description: The number of contacts that have opened the message.

column.name: plaintext
column.description: For email messages, the plain text version of your email. For SMS messages, the content to be sent.

column.name: reply_to_email
column.description: The \

column.name: resource
column.description: A JSON Object with properties that represent the full data of the message, include its status, blocks, and more.

column.name: send_from_email
column.description: The email address from which the message was sent. The email address set as the account default is used unless a custom address is provided via this field.

column.name: send_out_name
column.description: If the `send_from_email` field is set to `custom` , the name the message should come from.

column.name: send_to
column.description: Used only with custom objects and SMS messages. In custom objects, you can use this field to send to another email in a parent/child relationship. For example, you could send to a related child object instead of the contact's default email address. The field is stored in the format `{related_field}//{child_field}` , where `related_field` is the parent field relating one object to another and `child_field` is the actual email field in the related object you would like to send to. For SMS messages, this field defaults to `sms_number` .

column.name: sent_count
column.description: The number of contacts the message was sent to.

column.name: spam_score
column.description: The SpamAssassin spam score of the message. The lower the score, the better the rating. Messages with a spam score of 5 or higher will not be sent.

column.name: subject
column.description: The email subject line.

column.name: transactional_email
column.description: A binary integer flag indicating whether or not this message is transactional email.

column.name: type
column.description: The message type.

column.name: unsubscribed_count
column.description: The number of contacts that clicked the unsubscribe link in the message to opt-out of future messages.

column.name: utm_tracking
column.description: A binary flag indicating whether or not the message contains UTM tracking information.

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

table.name: PeterpmTask
table.description: A task object is created when a task is assigned to a contact or other object.

column.name: assignee_id
column.description: The user who has control of the task.

column.name: outcome_id
column.description: If the task has an outcome, the ID of that outcome. Task outcomes are user-defined and stored as a related object.

column.name: task_id
column.description: The ID of the task message. The task message is the generic template the task was created from.

column.name: date_assigned
column.description: The date and time the task was assigned.

column.name: date_complete
column.description: The date and time the task was marked as completed.

column.name: date_due
column.description: The date and time the task should be completed by.

column.name: details
column.description: The content of the task message.

column.name: hidden
column.description: Whether the Task is accessible, meaning it has not been deleted.

column.name: notifications
column.description: A JSON encoded string including information about sent notifications.

column.name: object_type_id
column.description: The ID of the type of object (aka \

column.name: rules
column.description: If the task has rules associated with it, the events, conditions and actions of those rules.

column.name: status
column.description: The task completion status.

column.name: step_num
column.description: If the task is a step in a sequence, the order in the sequence of that step.

column.name: subject
column.description: The subject line of the task email.

column.name: type
column.description: The task type.

table.name: PeterpmPropertyBuildingFeaturesOption
table.description: A many-to-many association between the PeterpmProperty model's records and the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model. The associations are derived from the PeterpmProperty model's building_features_options_as_text field, which contains a textual representation of all selected options as a concatenated string with custom separators. However, the textual representation makes it impossible to perform efficient searches. As a result, the building_features_options_as_text field's value is inflated into records on this model to build a proper many-to-many association at the database level. See the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model for full details, as that model is necessary to derive the name of the options referenced by the `optionId` foreign field on this model. Note that for this relationship, the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model's `objectId` field = "10001" and its `fieldId` field = "f3274". This is useful when searching the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model directly for options applicable to the PeterpmProperty model's building_features_options_as_text field, although typically you will use this model (PeterpmPropertyBuildingFeaturesOption) when querying for options since it contains the `recordId` property to understand what options a record is associated with.

column.name: id
column.description: The ID of the PeterpmPropertyBuildingFeaturesOption. This is generated automatically by combining the `optionId` and `recordId` values.

column.name: optionId
column.description: The optionId assigned by Ontraport. This references the `id` on the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model, making it possible to join this model to the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model to reference the name of the option. Users are only familiar with the option name, not its numeric ID. This ID represents a single entry in the PeterpmProperty model's building_features_options_as_text field (the text field with a serialized representation of all options associated with the record).

column.name: recordId
column.description: The ID of the PeterpmProperty record that the option is associated with.

table.name: PeterpmDealNoiseSignsOption
table.description: A many-to-many association between the PeterpmDeal model's records and the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model. The associations are derived from the PeterpmDeal model's noise_signs_options_as_text field, which contains a textual representation of all selected options as a concatenated string with custom separators. However, the textual representation makes it impossible to perform efficient searches. As a result, the noise_signs_options_as_text field's value is inflated into records on this model to build a proper many-to-many association at the database level. See the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model for full details, as that model is necessary to derive the name of the options referenced by the `optionId` foreign field on this model. Note that for this relationship, the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model's `objectId` field = "149" and its `fieldId` field = "f2505". This is useful when searching the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model directly for options applicable to the PeterpmDeal model's noise_signs_options_as_text field, although typically you will use this model (PeterpmDealNoiseSignsOption) when querying for options since it contains the `recordId` property to understand what options a record is associated with.

column.name: id
column.description: The ID of the PeterpmDealNoiseSignsOption. This is generated automatically by combining the `optionId` and `recordId` values.

column.name: optionId
column.description: The optionId assigned by Ontraport. This references the `id` on the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model, making it possible to join this model to the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model to reference the name of the option. Users are only familiar with the option name, not its numeric ID. This ID represents a single entry in the PeterpmDeal model's noise_signs_options_as_text field (the text field with a serialized representation of all options associated with the record).

column.name: recordId
column.description: The ID of the PeterpmDeal record that the option is associated with.

The associations are derived from the PeterpmDeal model's pest_active_times_options_as_text field, which contains a textual representation of all selected options as a concatenated string with custom separators. However, the textual representation makes it impossible to perform efficient searches. The associations are derived from the PeterpmJob model's noise_signs_options_as_text field, which contains a textual representation of all selected options as a concatenated string with custom separators. See the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model for full details, as that model is necessary to derive the name of the options referenced by the `optionId` foreign field on this model. Note that for this relationship, the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model's `objectId` field = "10000" and its `fieldId` field = "f2497". This is useful when searching the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model directly for options applicable to the PeterpmJob model's noise_signs_options_as_text field, although typically you will use this model (PeterpmJobNoiseSignsOption) when querying for options since it contains the `recordId` property to understand what options a record is associated with.

column.name: id
column.description: The ID of the PeterpmJobNoiseSignsOption. This is generated automatically by combining the `optionId` and `recordId` values.

column.name: optionId
column.description: The optionId assigned by Ontraport. This references the `id` on the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model, making it possible to join this model to the PeterpmOntraportListFieldOption model to reference the name of the option. Users are only familiar with the option name, not its numeric ID. This ID represents a single entry in the PeterpmJob model's noise_signs_options_as_text field (the text field with a serialized representation of all options associated with the record).

column.name: recordId
column.description: The ID of the PeterpmJob record that the option is associated with.
